item.title: Starmer Emerges From UK Welfare Fight Weaker and Billions in Red
item.description: Keir Starmer dramatically abandoned his flagship welfare reforms to avoid a historic defeat, leaving the UK prime minister’s authority badly damaged and his government facing a widening fiscal hole to fill.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes, Lucy White, Ailbhe Rea

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer, UK prime minister, during a meeting with Dick Schoof, Netherlands' prime minister, not pictured, at 10 Downing Street in London, UK, on Thursday, Feb. 6, 2025. The closer the Labour government aligns the British economy with the EU's — as it promised to do in July's election — the less room it has for maneuver to accommodate US demands on trade.

item.title: Macron Opens Iran Talks With Putin in First Call Since 2022
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron and Vladimir Putin agreed to coordinate their approach on Iran in their first phone call since 2022, marking a rare overture from a European head to the Russian leader.
item.dc:creator: Samy Adghirni, Daryna Krasnolutska

media:content.media:description: French President Emmanuel Macron. Photographer: Benoit Tessier/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Mexico Congress Backs Bill to Overhaul Telecoms Regulations
item.description: Mexico’s lower house approved the general text of a watered-down bill to overhaul telecommunications regulations, after the proposal’s initial draft provoked objections that the government was seeking to censor critical media.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vasquez

media:content.media:description: Claudia Sheinbaum

item.title: Costa Rica Court Votes to Revoke Presidential Immunity
item.description: A Costa Rican court voted to revoke President Rodrigo Chaves’s immunity in a case of alleged influence peddling.
item.dc:creator: Michael D McDonald

media:content.media:description: Costa Rica's President Rodrigo Chaves

item.title: The American Toymaker Suing Trump Over Destructive Tariffs
item.description: Today on the Big Take Asia podcast: US companies are grappling with tariff challenges on their Chinese supply chains. How one toymaker is fighting back.
item.dc:creator: Yang Yang, Naomi Ng, K Oanh Ha

media:content.media:description: Boxes with Learning Resources Inc. toys in Shenzhen, China. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: FBI to Keep Headquarters in Washington as Lawmakers Protest
item.description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation plans to move its headquarters to the Ronald Reagan Building complex in Washington, scuttling Biden administration plans approved by Congress to move the agency to the Maryland suburbs.
item.dc:creator: Chris Strohm

media:content.media:description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation headquarters in Washington, DC.

item.title: What’s in the Trump Tax Bill That Just Passed the Senate
item.description: President Donald Trump’s multitrillion-dollar tax and spending package moved closer to reality after it passed the Senate Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Alicia Diaz

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington on June 30. Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

item.title: Senate Tax Bill Strikes Clean Energy But Leaves Room for Relief
item.description: The Senate version of President Donald Trump’s tax-and-spending bill would soften the blow for wind and solar developers, which had feared a sharp reduction in subsidies that helped spur a renewable power boom in the past few years. But the bill now faces conservatives in the House of Representatives eager to kill those credits.
item.dc:creator: Josh Saul, Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: Workers install solar panels at a home in San Francisco.

item.title: Trump Tax Bill Hits Republican Resistance in House Ahead of Vote
item.description: Donald Trump’s multitrillion-dollar tax bill is running into Republican resistance in the House as moderate and ultra-conservative GOP lawmakers threaten to defy the president and sink his domestic agenda.
item.dc:creator: Alicia Diaz, Cam Kettles, Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: Representative Jim McGovern, a Democrat from Massachusetts and ranking member of the House Rules Committee, center left, speaks during a hearing at the US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, July 1, 2025. Donald Trump’s $3.3 trillion tax and spending cut bill passed the Senate Tuesday after a furious push by Republican leaders to persuade holdouts to back the legislation and hand the president a political win.

item.title: Trump Tax Bill Progresses, But GOP Disquiet Over Medicaid Persists
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Today, politics and health care reporter Rachel Cohrs Zhang analyzes the ramifications of what President Donald Trump’s One Big Beautiful Bill will do to Medicaid and its recipients. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Cohrs Zhang

media:content.media:description: Senator Thom Tillis during a vote-a-rama at the US Capitol on July 1. Photographer: Graeme Sloan/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Sticks With July 9 Tariff Deadline While Criticizing Japan
item.description: President Donald Trump said he is not considering delaying his July 9 deadline for higher tariffs to resume and renewed his threat to cut off talks and impose duty rates on several nations, including Japan.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy, Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: Container ships at the Yokkaichi Port in Yokkaichi, Japan.

item.title: Chipmakers Win Bigger Tax Credit Under Bill Passed by Senate
item.description: Sweeping tax legislation passed by the Senate Tuesday would make it cheaper for semiconductor manufacturers to build plants in the US, delivering a win to chipmakers and boosting US efforts to expand the industry domestically.
item.dc:creator: Alicia Diaz, Mackenzie Hawkins

media:content.media:description: Construction at the site of Micron Technology new semiconductor factory in Boise, Idaho.

item.title: NOAA Budget Cuts to Gut Climate Research, Slash Jobs
item.description: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is proposing cutting about 18% of its workforce and slashing $1.5 billion from its budget, including terminating programs to protect coastal communities and research that supports better forecasts and natural disaster prediction.
item.dc:creator: Brian K Sullivan, Lou Del Bello

media:content.media:description: A tropical analysis meteorologist at his station at the NOAA research center in Miami.

item.title: Trump Accused by 20 States of Sharing Medicaid Data With ICE
item.description: Twenty state attorneys general are seeking to block the Trump administration from sharing personal health data with the Department of Homeland Security for immigration enforcement in a lawsuit to be filed Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Cassandre Coyer

media:content.media:description: An ICE agent stands outside of immigration court hearings at Jacob K. Javits Federal Building in New York, on June 10.

item.title: French Premier Survives No-Confidence Vote as Far Right Abstains
item.description: France’s minority government on Tuesday survived a no-confidence motion over the pension reform thanks to Marine Le Pen’s far-right party abstaining in the vote.
item.dc:creator: Samy Adghirni

media:content.media:description: Francois Bayrou speaks at the French National Assembly in Paris on July 1. Photographer: Julien De Rosa/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Columbia Receives Warning That Its Accreditation Is at Risk
item.description: Columbia University received a warning that its accreditation may be “in jeopardy” from the Middle States Commission on Higher Education, which cited “insufficient evidence” that the school is in compliance with certain standards like fostering a respectful campus climate.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Rembert

media:content.media:description: Students on the Columbia University campus in New York. Photographer: Charly Triballeau/AFP

item.title: Lula Fights to Tax the Rich in Preview of 2026 Election Battle
item.description: Brazil’s Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva picked a fight with Congress over taxation of the rich, offering an early glimpse of political and economic debates that are set to rage through the country’s presidential election next year.
item.dc:creator: Martha Viotti Beck, Simone Iglesias, Daniel Carvalho

media:content.media:description: Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva

item.title: Macron Briefed Zelenskiy on His Call With Putin, People Say
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron has reached out to Volodomyr Zelenskiy to brief him about his phone call with Russian President Vladimir Putin on Tuesday, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Daryna Krasnolutska, Samy Adghirni

media:content.media:description: Volodymyr Zelenskiy, left, and Emmanuel Macron on the sidelines of the two-day NATO's Heads of State and Government summit in The Hague on June 24, 2025.

item.title: Muni Market Poised for ‘Space Bonds’ With New Senate Tax Bill
item.description: The municipal-bond market is poised to go to infinity — and beyond — with a new financing tool included in President Donald Trump’s tax and spending bill that passed the Senate Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Albright

media:content.media:description: The Vulcan rocket on the United Launch Alliance (ULA) launchpad at the Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in Cape Canaveral, Florida, US, on Wed. Dec. 6, 2023. Project Kuiper could transform Amazon into a telecommunications giant, but first the company needs to loft more than 3,000 satellites into orbit.

item.title: Florida Taps Contractors With No Detention Experience for ‘Alligator Alcatraz’
item.description: On June 20, nearly three weeks into the Atlantic hurricane season, Florida disaster-management officials assembled a group of emergency relief contractors in Tallahassee and asked them to do something they had never done before.
item.dc:creator: Michael Smith, Sophie Alexander, Rachel Adams-Heard

media:content.media:description: Generators are driven into Dade Collier Training and Transition Airport in Ochopee, Florida.

item.title: Ghana to Seek India’s Backing for Vaccine Hub as Modi Visits
item.description: Ghana plans to ask India for support to develop a vaccine hub when Prime Minister Narendra Modi visits the West African nation this week.
item.dc:creator: Ekow Dontoh

media:content.media:description: A health worker prepares a Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine at the Ridge Hospital in Accra, Ghana, on March 2, 2021.

item.title: Cuomo Weighs Next Steps as Mamdani Scores Big Win in NYC Primary
item.description: Andrew Cuomo is weighing his next move after democratic socialist Zohran Mamdani clinched the Democratic nomination for mayor of New York City by a staggering 12-point margin over the former governor.
item.dc:creator: Laura Nahmias, Gregory Korte

media:content.media:description: Zohran Mamdani at a campaign event on June 23

item.title: Trump Risks Voter Blowback as ‘One Big Beautiful Bill’ Moves Forward
item.description: The US Senate handed President Donald Trump a major political victory with its Tuesday passage of a sweeping domestic policy bill, bringing him one step closer to a signature legislative achievement in an administration that has largely governed through executive power.
item.dc:creator: Hadriana Lowenkron

media:content.media:description: Senator Thom Tillis during a vote-a-rama at the US Capitol in Washington on Tuesday.

item.title: Rubio Unleashes Fresh Broadside Against USAID on Its Final Day
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio issued a fresh broadside against USAID on the agency’s last day of existence, defending the Trump administration’s move to deny funding to programs that proponents argue have saved millions of lives.
item.dc:creator: Eric Martin

media:content.media:description: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio

item.title: Polish Supreme Court Validates Nawrocki’s Presidential Victory
item.description: Poland’s Supreme Court validated the victory of the opposition candidate Karol Nawrocki in last month’s presidential election amid controversy about voting irregularities.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Krasuski

media:content.media:description: Karol Nawrocki addresses supporters during an election night event at the Mala Warszawa Theatre in Warsaw, on June 1.

item.title: Starmer’s Welfare Overhaul Hangs in Balance Ahead of Vote
item.description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer is girding for what could be the most consequential vote of his premiership, with dozens of Labour rebels expecting to vote against the government’s welfare overhaul despite huge concessions to push it through parliament.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White, Ailbhe Rea

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer Source: UK Parliament

item.title: US Gives Birthright Case Judge Assurances Amid Deportation Fears
item.description: The US Justice Department told a skeptical judge that the government won’t apply President Donald Trump’s executive order on birthright citizenship to affected immigrants before July 27, when the US Supreme Court’s 30-day pause on the directive expires.
item.dc:creator: Erik Larson

media:content.media:description: Women and their children arrive at a bus station following release from Customs and Border Protection in McAllen, Texas.

item.title: Trump’s Tax Bill Passes US Senate as Republicans Notch Major Win
item.description: Donald Trump’s $3.3 trillion tax and spending cut bill passed the Senate Tuesday after a furious push by Republican leaders to persuade holdouts to back the legislation and hand the president a political win.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Steven T. Dennis, Emily Birnbaum

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump

item.title: Putin Offers Special Account to Lure New Investors to Russia
item.description: President Vladimir Putin signed a decree in an attempt to attract new foreign investment into Russia’s financial markets, despite sweeping sanctions over the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Kira Zavyalova

media:content.media:description: Vladimir Putin Photographer: Alexander Nemenov/Getty Images

item.title: Senators to Vote on Trump’s Tax Bill After Deal, Thune Says
item.description: Senate Majority Leader John Thune said his chamber will soon vote on passage of President Donald Trump’s tax and spending bill after securing enough support to pass the legislation.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Emily Birnbaum, Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: Senator Lisa Murkowski
